docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Have we lost all understanding of what insurance is supposed to be? No one in America should have to bear the burden of catastrophic medical expenses. As insurance companies have morphed into major financial institutions, with all of the fancy new missions, visions and branding exercises of the modern corporation, perhaps it is time to remind them of the purpose of insurance.

Bloomberg and his Democratic opponent, Fernando Ferrer, laid out similar health care agendas yesterday, each promising to enroll more than 200,000 children in Medicaid and other government health plans, and to invest in medical technology. Both campaigns insisted that the timing was purely coincidental, but it led the Ferrer camp to accuse Mr. Bloomberg again of copying his opponent's ideas and claiming them as his own. The Ferrer campaign has accused him of doing the same with its proposals on housing and after-school programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Sharon and Arnold Dorsett, featured in ''When Even Health Insurance Is No Safeguard,'' had no way to know that the seemingly common symptoms afflicting their son would require an expensive remedy to combat. And if they had known, would anything have been different? Insurance options are limited by what an employer offers or what an individual or family can afford. Because of ever-increasing rates, these options involve more cost-sharing by patients. This cost-sharing is in essence cost-shifting to patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just in time for Halloween, the usual yearly ritual of terror by headline is now playing itself out in medical offices everywhere. Last year it revolved around flu shots; a few years ago it was anthrax and smallpox; a few years before that it was the ''flesh-eating bacteria''; and before that it was Ebola virus, and Lyme disease and so on back into the distant past. This year it's the avian flu. ''I was crossing Third Avenue yesterday and I was coughing so hard I had to stop and barely made it across,'' a patient told me last week. ''I'm really scared I'm getting the avian flu.''

docs.lead_paragraph: When a little-known transplant surgeon named Bill Frist decided to enter politics in 1994, he relied on his family's fortune and name to catapult him to the Senate. From the moment he arrived in Washington, Mr. Frist, now the Republican leader, has made health care his signature issue. But as the senator lays the groundwork for a possible presidential bid in 2008, he is finding that that his family ties may be as much a hindrance as a help.

docs.lead_paragraph: IS there celebration in the halls of Citibank this week? Is MBNA uncorking the Champagne while Ford Motor Credit serves cake? Eleven years ago, these and other creditors pushed hard to re-elect sympathetic members of Congress who would enact a tougher bankruptcy law. Last Monday, the law they lobbied for went into effect. It was a long fight -- President Bill Clinton vetoed one bill, anti-abortion forces derailed another -- but in the end the credit industry succeeded in making it much harder for struggling families to ease their debt loads. The industry helped fend off efforts to soften the bankruptcy bill's impact on soldiers fighting overseas and on victims of natural disasters. It even turned thumbs down on an amendment to limit enforcement of debts that carried more than 100 percent interest.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Elizabeth Warren on fluid nature of bankruptcy laws, which are written and rewritten as new economic problems surface; says current law punishes debtors but does not give money to creditors, who will discover bill promises more than it delivers; says law will not solve underlying problems or stop natural disasters; says politicians will realize that those who find themselves in bankruptcy are solidly middle-class people who have been laid low by forces beyond their control, and once again laws will have to change (M)
docs.snippet: Punishing debtors with the new bankruptcy law won't put money in creditors' pockets.

[Page C1.] How a New Employee Uncovered an Unusual Refco Loan Peter F. James had been working at Refco for less than two months when he noticed something this summer that teams of accountants had apparently missed for years. Mr. James, recently hired in the controller's office, wondered why a larger-than-normal interest payment had been made to Refco on an outstanding loan made by the company. In August he started to ask questions, eventually taking his concerns to the chief financial officer. The answers would eventually lead to the departure of the chief executive and the rapid unraveling of the firm, prompting its filing for bankruptcy protection last week. [C1.] Village Voice to Be Acquired by Publisher Group The company that publishes The Village Voice and five other alternative newspapers is to announce today an agreement to be acquired by New Times Media, the largest publisher in the market. The deal would create a chain of 17 free weekly newspapers around the country with a combined circulation of 1.8 million. The merger will undoubtedly raise questions about whether The Voice and its siblings can preserve their anti-establishment roots as part of a growing corporation. [C1.] Used and Useless Computers Litter Developing Countries Much of the used computer equipment sent from the United States to developing countries for use in homes, schools and businesses is often neither usable nor reparable, creating enormous environmental problems in some of the world's poorest places, according to a report to be issued today by an environmental organization. The report says that the unusable equipment is being donated or sold to developing nations by recycling businesses in the United States as a way to dodge the expense of having to recycle it properly. The report, prepared by the Basel Action Network of Seattle, focuses on Nigeria, in western Africa, but says the situation is similar throughout much of the developing world. [C5.] Movie Directors Bring New Skill to Video Games The line between movies and video games is blurring. Major movie studios, with libraries of movies, want to make video games, and video game makers see potential in movies. And now a new generation of movie directors who grew up playing video games are bringing their storytelling skills to that world. [C1.] Cisco Develops Technology for Radio Communication Cisco Systems plans to announce a new method for marrying the frequently incompatible radio gear used by emergency service agencies and businesses, using an Internet telephone standard. The approach is aimed at connecting the diverse array of push-to-talk radio systems with other voice and data systems without the expense of replacing the existing systems. [C5.] Consumer Blogs Get Attention From Product Makers As the number of blogs has grown, more consumers are keeping Web diaries dedicated exclusively to their favorite brands. Most of these, like one maintained by Darren Rovell, left, who compiles articles and commentary on Gatorade, are done without the consent of the companies that own the brands, but some companies are starting to pay attention, using the blogs as a kind of informal network of consumer opinion. [C6.] Criticism of Yahoo Disclosure in China Rises Yahoo has suffered a good deal of opprobrium since it was revealed last month that, when government officials came calling, the company's Hong Kong division simply surrendered information on a Chinese citizen who had presumably sought anonymity in a Yahoo e-mail address. Yahoo contends that it must obey the laws of the land in which it operates, but the online reaction is growing more critical. Link by Link: Tom Zeller Jr. [C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Florida is about to experiment with a radical change in its Medicaid program in a desperate attempt to rein in the upward spiraling costs of the program. The pilot project is based on a cherished belief of conservative health analysts -- that consumer choice and competition among health plans will improve the quality of care and hold down costs. While there's reason to wonder if those theories will hold up, Florida has been responsible and serious in preparing this test. It makes sense to give it a try, while watching carefully to make sure some of the poorest and most vulnerable people in the country do not suffer as guinea pigs. The Florida experiment, which was approved last week by the federal government but needs final approval from the State Legislature, would start by transferring more than 200,000 Medicaid beneficiaries in two counties to managed care plans. Certain categories of patients would have to join managed care plans, which they would select with the help of a ''choice counselor.'' Florida's Medicaid program would pay the plan a premium for their care, adjusted to reflect the health status of the patient.
docs.abstract: Editorial supports Florida experiment with radical changes in its Medicaid program despite some skepticism about plan, which will shift more than 200,000 beneficiaries in two counties to managed care plans; says it is not clear that managed care can do better job than Medicaid, as Medicaid is notoriously parsimonious in reimbursing doctors and hospitals; says beneficiaries are often poorly educated and may have difficulty navigating system; says Florida's plan is first to inject competition and consumer choice into Medicaid and may well serve as model for other states if it works out
docs.snippet: While there may be risks in Florida's plan to inject competition and consumer choice into Medicaid, the experiment is surely worth a try.
